[h1] ¡Jugadoras de todos los países, uníos! [/h1]
Portal 2 lleva todavía más lejos el aspecto que hizo triunfar al Portal original, por encima de la tarta y la sorpresa inicial: la pura mecánica. Y es que las posibilidades pueden ser infinitas, como vemos al introducir los cubos de pintura en la mecánica jugable (la mayor innovación con respecto a su predecesor). 

No todo queda ahí; si el primer juego articulaba la experiencia con la equiparación entre la protagonista y el usuario en un gozoso juego metatextual (es decir, era más psicológico), Portal 2 se erige como un juego "militante" y social, donde conceptos como "lucha de clases" o "sororidad" resuenan con mucha fuerza (aunque no explícitamente), adelantándose a la "agenda política" y a las "cuotas" imperantes hoy en día.

Quizá sea menos "mítico", pero es más largo, más difícil, más entretenido y tan gracioso como ese. A destacar su nivel y curva de dificultad (y aprendizaje), ejemplares.

Ojalá Valve se decida a hacer un Portal 3, que no será nada menos que otro juego inolvidable de puzles, y seguramente otro juego que hable de nuestra relación con el medio y con nuestro tiempo.

[b]Single-Player[/b]: Portal 2's solo campaign is paced brilliantly with a smooth difficulty curve for the first 5 chapters, introducing new gameplay features like the lasers, light bridges and tractor beams. The sixth and seventh chapters are noticeably more time-consuming, but this comes more from slightly annoying level design than it does from raw challenge. While the first 5 chapters take place mostly within test chambers, chapters 6 and 7 take place in the old ruins of Aperture Science. The change in scenery means a lot of the puzzles boil down to finding the one isolated white spot you can actually shoot a portal on, which does drag down the pacing and excitement factor the game had going for it up until that point. This is almost completely made up for by the propulsion, repulsion and conversion gels, which are probably the most fun new gameplay element introduced since Portal 1 however. The campaign then picks up again in the final two chapters, and although the final boss could have been a bit more challenging, at least it isn't as much of a pushover as GLaDOS from Portal 1. The game never really rises to the consistently "perfect" level of challenge of Portal 1, but that's were the co-op comes in.

[b]Co-Operative[/b]: Portal 2 also comes with a co-op campaign which not only addresses Portal 1 fans who may not have gotten the difficulty they wanted from Portal 2's slight downgrade in difficulty, but provides the most difficult test chambers in all of Portal. The campaign is completely separate from the single-player, features two charismatic playable characters, and brings along GLaDOS for company. The game designers thought ahead and included a gesture system to point out specific spots if the players don't have mics and you can even see your teammate's point of view by pressing Tab. The test chambers always take the two-player count into consideration in the level design, and having to work with another person makes the game incredibly difficult in a good way. The game also added split-screen support post-launch which is an incredibly convenient and pro-consumer move, even if its actual use might be niche amongst players. More cross-platform developers should bring split-screen over to PC when they've already implemented its code on console versions, so it's good to see Valve bring it to Portal 2.

[b]Workshop[/b]: Although I don't mess around with it much, Portal 2 also features near infinite content as the Community Workshop consistently brings in new, quality content for the game entirely for free, I'd still like to see Portal 3 myself though.

[b]Verdict[/b]: Overall, a must play for any one into video games, and the simple gameplay (with the game's complexity coming from the sandbox and later-introduced gameplay features) also makes it a great introduction game for casuals. If Steam used a 1-10 system, I'd give the game a 9 or 9.5, really my only criticism is the single-player could have been a little harder and chapters 5 and 6 could have been tightened up a bit. Flawless in every other way.

Much like portal, Core mechanics of this master piece include use of instant travelling (warp hole) portals, weighted objects (like companion cube), and surface modifying gel (like blue bounce gel) to reach a checkpoint from where you go another level and core loop starts. 

For the Dynamics, your main aim is to get out of Aperture Labs because you are being treated as guinea pig and you're too tenacious let GLADOS (an awesome AI who loves science and experiment (and in some cases just to kill you, you know, the usual)) get the best of you. 

Art style is amazing, lab and level design helps player telling them what to do but still making it challenging.  

If you are a puzzle person, love to drop-in at one place and end up in another place (much like those drunk nights) and enjoy a well orchestrated story line, this game is for you.
If you can imaging what i mean by saying all this, "Now you're thinking with portals".
